number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 9, 2014
												Octodad: Dadliest Catch is straight out a true original. With polished graphics and a basic story it proves to be a delight to play. There was one part in the last level which did get pretty ridiculously hard as of precision walking needed. This part did get pretty frustrating and I only got through it by winging it by throwing his legs everywhere till I could reach the next checkpoint. Bar this, the game was just about flawless. Each level provides plenty silliness having you performing quite simple everday tasks.  There's usually no punishment for failing these tasks allowing you to laugh at♥♥♥♥♥♥ups. There are areas where you may be watched where making mistakes can add up to retrying. However, there's a freeplay mode to allow you to go back to levels and be as ridiculous as you can be. I was not disappointed with Octodad. I was even surprised by how much fun I've had with it. The end does do something that will probably surprise you all. It is a short game but its length fits it. With Steam workshop there's certainly much more nonsense to come. Well worth the full price, trust me.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 24, 2014
												I got to wear a lot of different ties. 10/10Seriously, though, this game is a wonderful sequel to the original Octodad. It's funny, it's a blast to play (and to watch other people play), and the basic premise is one of the most strange, charming, and creative I've ever seen in any game. It took everything that I loved about the first game and made it better--the controls feel tighter, the music is EXCELLENT, and the ties are weirdly satisfying as a collectable. Aside from ONE UNNECESSARILY DIFFICULT PART AT THE END, lots of the tasks in the game are just challenging enough to feel rewarding upon completion, but never so tough that they're frustrating (aside from the aforementioned part).Whatever Young Horses does next, I'm on board. Octodad lives!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
												I came into this game expecting very little.  After all, the premise is that you're an octopus in a suit and "nobody suspects a thing".  The controls in the game are purposely frustrating, adding to the game's humorous tone.  Thankfully, it was never so frustrating that I felt compelled to throw things.  Some of the earlier tasks in the game were fun to complete.  Most later tasks, however, involved walking (if that's what you call it) from one side of a room to another and picking something up.  By this point in the game, the novelty of being an octopus has worn off.  I would like to say the game is too short, but it couldn't possibly keep itself going longer than it did.  Nevertheless, I would definitely recommend this to anyone with a sense of humor.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22, 2014
												If you're looking for a long narrative in Octodad, don't expect one. It doesn't have a long storyline to it. But this, however surprisingly, isn't that deterring to the game's quality. Yes, it may be short, but in that short time, they were able to show an emotional story of fatherhood and fear of exposure that will probably get you in your soft spot. The game has so much replay value in it's Free Play mode (Fully unlocked after completing the story), even if it's simply flopping around and being silly. And while the collectables *could* have been expanded, the ties are still a great thing to hunt after.Where the game gets it true replay value, howeverm is in the Workshop. Young Horses has graciously given us access to the same level editor they used to make the story levels in Octodad. So now, in the future, you could potentially expect this game to be like Happy Wheels, the community banding together to make more great abnd original levels, and Young Horses giving new items and new physics to the game.All in all, Octodad isn't for everyone. But if you like a game that you can just relax and goof off with, I'd definetly reccomend this for you.

content:
Posted: April 2, 2014
												Octodad is a hilariously fun game. It’s got some pretty fun controls. Think QWOP, Surgeon Simulator or Probably Archery, but unlike these, the controls actually make the frustration fun. The physics really make this game golden. It’s a bummer that there’s no co-op online, only local. You play as Octodad performing seemingly mindless tasks made difficult by the fact that your mouse controls your arms and legs. The dialogue is hilarious, and with a little patience and sheer determination you’re sure to have fun with this game. It’s a lot better than flailing around your keyboard trying to hop over the finish line, pecking at keys in hopes of not killing your patient, and a lot better than frustratingly trying to nock and arrow. Fresh and colorful with cheerful music and graphics, this game is a fun play. 7/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 5, 2014
												Nobody would ever suspect that a dumb physics game about an octopus could become popular.  Yet here we are with a sequel now full-blown with achievements, storyline and age-appropriate voice acting.  The continuing saga of everybody's new favourite cephalopod is an absolute blast to play and surprisingly not so difficult as some people claim it to be, once you've learnt how axis work again.Dadliest Catch is a much sharper, smoother and longer experience than the first game as well as most electric shaver commercials claim to be.  It is a paradigm of simplicity, in that trying to do simple actions while having the most obstructive controls should not be a popular game.  In fact that would be the very antithesis of a bad game.  Yet it's not.What really makes the game work is that there's a REASON for the odd control, you are an octopus pretending to be a human, and that makes it alright.  That makes it excusable, it's funny, it's dumb, it's brilliant and very appropriate.  The music is charming and very 1950s with the main theme rocking towards the 60s' style, the characters are all very charming people and you will never believe how much there is to know about Kelp.Like, seriously, there's a lot of kelp stuff you can learn in this game.But the point is, Octodad's second/full and proper game is an absolute blast to play if your PC can run smooth.  It's an adorable idealised world, the protagonist is one of the nicest guys in gaming and the concept is genuinely fun to play with the entirety of struggling to control him being actually really entertaining.  If you're the sort of person who can just fall back into the waters of enjoying a game for its absurdity, then Octodad is waiting for you.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 18, 2014
												I was a Kickstarter of the original Octodad, donating quite a bit after the ingenuity of the original game. I waited a couple of years for the release of Octodad 2: Dadliest Catch, and the wait was definitely worth it. Octodad 2 builds on the quirkiness of the original wonderfully, allowing us to continue on as a Normal Everyday Father who, plagued with incredibly awkward controls, tries to continue living a Normal Everyday Life, without his Secret Identity being revealed.The controls have to be mentioned. They're weird, and they're awesome. At first, the controls are cumbersome and incredibly difficult to use, but after 10 or 20 minutes, after you get to grips with it, it's almost like being in control of a flight simulator. You "get it", and using and perfecting the movement is very satisfying. The game itself is funny and original, and the perfect length for what it's trying to do, not too short, but not too long. The achievements are cool and add some extra replayability, with an option to time your run for speedrunners (one of the few games I've seen to ever do this!)So yeah, I thoroughly recommend this game, I am a very happy backer of this project.Nilesy

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 1, 2014
												Octodad: Dadliest Catch is a game about destruction, deception, and fatherhood. The player controls Octodad, a dapper octopus masquerading as a human, as he goes about his life. Octodad's existence is a constant struggle, as he must master mundane tasks with his unwieldy boneless tentacles while simultaneously keeping his cephalopodan nature a secret from his human family.Octodad is a great example of a game that conveys a message through gameplay. In conjunction with its story, characters, and setting, the controls offer an empathetic look into the life of an extreme outsider trying to fit in and trying to do right by his family...I love that. Gaming is growing up, and Octodad is some of the best evidence of that.Smartly built, endlessly entertaining, and unexpectedly heartwarming, Dadliest Catch manages to turn an utterly ridiculous concept into one of the most surprising games in recent memory.Would recomend!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 2, 2014
												Octodad is a hilariously fun game. It’s got some pretty fun controls. Think QWOP, Surgeon Simulator or Probably Archery, but unlike these, the controls actually make the frustration fun. The physics really make this game golden. It’s a bummer that there’s no co-op online, only local. You play as Octodad performing seemingly mindless tasks made difficult by the fact that your mouse controls your arms and legs. The dialogue is hilarious, and with a little patience and sheer determination you’re sure to have fun with this game. It’s a lot better than flailing around your keyboard trying to hop over the finish line, pecking at keys in hopes of not killing your patient, and a lot better than frustratingly trying to nock and arrow. Fresh and colorful with cheerful music and graphics, this game is a fun play. 7/10

content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
												Octodad is a wonderful 3D Adventure Game. While the puzzles are mostly very easy, you will spend quite some time controling Octodad. As being an Octopus on land is quite a struggle, the game recreates this wonderfully with the well designed complex controlsystem and the fact that people will get suspicious if you go all Octo and no Dad. The humor is delightful and even though the whole thing only takes about 3 hours it was a magical time, helping a cute Octopus to be a good father and Husband too his slighty delusional family, that does not seem to take notice of you being clearly no human. The Steam Workshop hopefully grants us many more great levels.

content:

												This is a cute game in the spirit of QWOP (but easier) where you control an octopus pretending to be a human. The story is short and has lots of variety, and I didn't get bored at all. The times when you're struggling with the controls (which are "good" but of course the point is trying to navigate this world using absurd octopus legs, which is inherently hard) can be a little frustrating, but that is the point, and the frustration usually leads to a chuckle at how ridiculous the premise is. I had a great time.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22, 2014
												If you're looking for a long narrative in Octodad, don't expect one. It doesn't have a long storyline to it. But this, however surprisingly, isn't that deterring to the game's quality. Yes, it may be short, but in that short time, they were able to show an emotional story of fatherhood and fear of exposure that will probably get you in your soft spot. The game has so much replay value in it's Free Play mode (Fully unlocked after completing the story), even if it's simply flopping around and being silly. And while the collectables *could* have been expanded, the ties are still a great thing to hunt after.Where the game gets it true replay value, howeverm is in the Workshop. Young Horses has graciously given us access to the same level editor they used to make the story levels in Octodad. So now, in the future, you could potentially expect this game to be like Happy Wheels, the community banding together to make more great abnd original levels, and Young Horses giving new items and new physics to the game.All in all, Octodad isn't for everyone. But if you like a game that you can just relax and goof off with, I'd definetly reccomend this for you.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 2, 2014
												Octodad is a very silly slapstick game with a boatload of charm. The main draw of the game is controlling Octodad through various human environments to accomplish certain objectives. The "octocontrols", which are very sensitive and slippery much like an octopus would be, look complicated at first, but are actually a lot of fun to play with and they never feel too cheap, but more like a learning curve that takes a while to adjust to. Octodad thankfully isn't a hard game either, save for a few parts where you need to be rather accurate with your tentacles. The characters range from the main squid himself who's a likable, determined, but nervous ball of ink, to well written family stereotypes, to having a pun-riddled chef as the main bad guy, to the various annoyed or eccentric human npcs that drive the satire home. The satire is part of the reason I consider Octodad's flaw to be it's length. The game has a great sense of humor, and even with all the achievements and the workshop support and the tie collecting it felt like a sample of something that could have been even bigger and funnier. I wanted more, and maybe I expected too much, but that in itself is evidence of how lovable this game can be.As a drawn out example, my favorite part of the game is the silly hats and outfits you can wear or put on as disguises, but it was heavily underutilized and not even necessary to progress in the game, besides the ones the game forces you to wear for the plot. You're an octopus pretending to be a human, that's what this game is about, so having an optional hitman-like disguise system would have added a lot of fun. If it ever gets a sequel I hope this is perhaps expanded upon. Despite my moaning about what could have been, I'm still going to recommend Octodad, though, because for what it's worth it's still enjoyable, humerous, slapsticky fun with a great sense of wit and enough extra content for replayability.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7, 2014
												Octodad is  a funny, quirky and unique experience, that I think everyone should try! I don't remember when was the last time a game has made me laugh and rage so much at the same time. The main mechanic is the frustrating controlls, which makes perfect sense, as you are trying to maneuver a boneless jelly blob around multiple areas full of stuff to break by "accident". The levels never overstay their welcome and there seems to be something new and fun stuff to do all the time.The game is a bit on the short side, but that's kind of expected, as there really is just one big mechanic to work with. I blazed through the game in couple of sittings and once you've finished, there's a slowly growing Steam workshop library stuff to mess around with. I may play through it again pretty soon and try to complete every achievement I missed on the first playthrough. I can wholeheartedly recommed Octodad to anyone who want's to laugh, cry and spot half a billion of pop culture references.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 3, 2014
												It's damn good, and certainly something you need to at least try. You may have heard complaints that it's too short, but all of those complaints are completely misguided. Yeah, it's short, but it's not too short. In fact, I'd argue that the length is pretty much perfect.It's nicely structured too. The first few levels are spent trying to perform ordinary tasks with the clumsy controls, the next few are spent performing a series of challenges to see if you've been paying attention, with the last few focused on wrapping up the story, while also experimenting with the gameplay a little.And to be honest that's all they can do, really. There's nowhere else they could've taken the concept. They could've made a few more levels but I much prefer the huge amount of attention paid to the current levels. It's short yeah, but that's because any unnecessary fluff has been cut off. I suspect I'll enjoy the game more than most people do, although I'm not sure why. I just find everything about Octodad himself endlessly entertaining. I haven't played any other game where even the act of moving your character is hilarious. I've seen some pretty dark comparisons to the story, relating it to alcoholisms and whatnot, but I think it's actually pretty lovely how he just tries to get on with his life despite being, y'know, an octopus.Okay I should probably stop rambling now.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 17, 2014
												Where do I start?  Octodad is a simulator that involves achieving basic human tasks, as a "basic human".  The charm of this game isn't the initially hilarious crazy physics engine (where destroying a room is a perfectly acceptable way to walk through it), but that it provides a brilliant parody to both itself, and the entire video game condition.  So much so, that the *explanatory blubber* provides a perfect reflection of exactly how we expect video games to respond to the circumstances of the scene, and go so far to illustrate the vast levels suspension of disbelief can take us.  So much so that the *game review blubber* isn't just a suitable shortcut for the dialogue, but is seemless and efficiently integrated into the game world.  Octodad is a near perfect parody of the essence of video games, but perhaps it goes a few steps too far.While Octodad certainly has its charm, it does fall short in a few areas.  Firstly, the narrative is far too short (given the price tag).  That's not to say it's not fulfilling, but it is noticeably tiny for how much it costs.  This is offset by the workshop, where a single Miley Cyrus mod alone makes the purchase worth it (if hilarious parodies are what you're into).  Unfortunately, the devs also decided that despite being a walking simulator, it needed to have increasing difficulty as the story progresses.  Some will find this acceptable, but I do not.  Given the small scope of the game (wrestling with walking and arm action physics), the artificial difficulty quickly goes from hilarious to frustrating.  You successfully scaled the mountain of hell?  Well, don't fall off trying to wrestle the physics engine through a tiny hole, or you'll be back to the start.  Finally succeeded in navigating a tiny plank with the most awkward of controls?  Well the devs thought it'd be a great idea to put breakable structures at the end of said path, and make you start again if you fail.Unfortunately, while the idea is admirable, being able to walk in this game only gets to the point of management, not mastery.  So you'll find yourself constantly wrestling with the game in an attempt to progress what would take you ten seconds in any other game (I was stuck in one room for about twenty minutes).  The novelty quickly wears off, and turns to frustration (intuitiveness is not this game's strength).  The tasks in the game are not so difficult, however wrestling with the game to do the task is.  A perfect example is trying to fill two wine glasses with wine.  Pray to god that you don't accidentally knock a glass over, because without rotational input, it's an absolute nightmare trying to reposition a glass back to it's proper orientation.  This is not a game you play to 'cool off' after a frustrating day.Still, Octodad scratches an itch that other games just can't.  While, as I mentioned earlier, the novelty wears off quick, the charm never does.  Even when you reach the point of despair, ready to hurl your computer against the wall, you'll find yourself firing it up a few hours or a few days or a few weeks later, just out of its uniqueness.  This game will test your patience, but it'll do so in a 'frustratingly ignorant puppy' kind of way.  My advice, if you do reach the point of despair (and alt-f4 just isn't an option), is to walk under a hand dryer.  You just can't stay mad at this game.The pros:Brilliant insight to the levels of suspension of disbelief a game can provide.Fantastic novelty item, with a decent framework hilarious moments and situations (biologists KNOW when they see a fish).Solid accompanying soundtrack, where even just a timed mouse click scene can get the adrenaline pumping.A few scenes that are far deeper than they appear on the surface.  My example for this is the *contented blubber* of a 'man' who has returned to something he loves, followed quickly by a *gameface* when remembering why he gave it up in the first place.Scratches a unique itch.The cons:Artificial and frustrating difficulty (do not play this game on a bad day!)A short and shallow storyShort-lived noveltyThe verdict?  Definitely pick this up if you're a novelty gamer.  Avoid if you like depth or intuitiveness.

content:
Posted: March 15, 2014
												So first thing I'm gonna say is that this game is just absolutely stupid. It's funny, it's great, but if you're not a fan of slapstick humour, you won't find half of the humour in this game funny.Octodad: Dadliest Catch is an... interesting game just to say the least. You play an octopus disguised as a human with a family. It's like, what? But, miraculously, it still makes a great game. The co-op feature in this game is absolutely hilarious. That's where most of my 4 hours of this game have went so far with friends. Characters are great, level design is great, and it's quite hard to hate. There are quite a few glitches too, but nothing that breaks the game. I finished the story with a very satisfied feeling, apart from the fact they don't explain at all where Tommy and Stacy come from...The only thing about this game is that it's very, very short. Unlike a huge title game, the campaign is very short. You can finish it in about an hour and a half, and, if you know what you're doing, probably under an hour.  Imagine all the other situations Octodad could get into! Imagine if he had to drive his kids to school? Imagine if he needed to go to a meeting? There are so many things that could have happened, but didn't. Really, my opinion is, if you're willing to pay $15 for a game that will provide with some humour, tortorus co-op and some Community Workshop items, buy this game. You won't regret, and there'll be at least one reference you didn't see in the first time playing. (e.g. In the shopping level, there's a type of pie that's called "Pewdie Pie." Genius.) But, if you're buying to get hours and hours out of the campaign, online multiplayer and other things from a big budget game, don't buy this game, because you'll be disappointed. I'm just a sort of person that likes creative games, and this is pretty creative, considering you have to do daily dad stuff as an octopus. Find me another game like that and you'll get $100.Workshop levels are also insane fun, like making zero gravity Octodad and 'Wrecking Blub.' Not sure if you wanna know but find out for yourself.In short, Octodad: Dadliest Catch is worth the money if it's your sort of game, but if you hate short campaigns and what not, but you still want to get the game, wait for a Steam sales to rob your wallet to buy this game.I'm going to give this game a 8/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 16, 2014
												Comedy is a rare thing in games. Some developers manage it with a witty script, others with outrageous characters that help lighten the mood, but few hit that holy grail of slapstick laugh out loud guffawing like Young Horses do in Octodad: Dadliest Catch.Octodad is just a typical guy, trying to make his way through life with his wife and two children, except that he is an octopus and he has the additional burden of keeping that a secret. Dressed in his snazzy suit, most people are none the wiser about his true identity, but suspicions rise when he is spotted acting strange.In addition to mouse and keyboard control, full game pad support is in place. I ended up preferring playing with a controller, but both work on the same principles. By default, players control three of Octodad's limbs: two legs and one arm. By manipulating their positions in space, Octodad can walk, run, climb, grab objects, and do all of the things a normal human being does. The kicker is that each limb is generally controlled one at a time, and they are all held together with an elasticity that often sends them off in unintended directions.The result is almost like handing a non-gamer a controller and putting him in the thick of a first-person shooter; there is a lot of flailing around and looking at the ground. It takes a certain amount of brain rewiring to be able to make Octodad move as intended, even when the necessary sequence of actions is cognitively clear.In any other game, these would be complaints, but Octodad is specifically about being uncomfortable and learning how to function in a body that is almost alien. For some, it may be frustrating, but for those willing to put in the effort, it is ultimately rewarding to learn how to function as an octopus in society. By the end, players should be able to walk competently without knocking things over or punching kids in the face too often.Being an octopus also affords Octodad some benefits that humans cannot reap, like the ability to squeeze into tight spots or to stretch out over large gaps. Young Horses built this awkward, difficult control scheme, and then crafted environments that take full advantage of its physics.Where the previous title was more of a proof of concept on the control scheme, Dadliest Catch delves a bit more deeply into Octodad lore. Revealed over the course of the campaign are how Octodad and his wife Scarlett met, when he decided to start masquerading as a human, and why the neighbourhood sushi chef wants to kill him so badly. Of course, how he and Scarlett managed to have two human children is jokingly brought up but never seriously addressed.You can't fault its originality, though. It's a game bursting with colour and personality, although the chirpy music does begin to grate after a while. It's hard not to love Octodad as he stumbles through life, and the levels are filled with cute references to indie games and developers, YouTubers such as SeaNanners and PewDiePie, and many more.Truly, Dadliest Catch realises how silly its concept is, and never takes itself too seriously. The writing fits the mood perfectly. Some of the off-hand remarks and terrible marine biology puns are worthy of a few laughs, but the general absurdity of the situation in its entirety is the biggest source of humor throughout the game.The silliness is conveyed well through the graphics and sound as well. Octodad lives in a colorful cartoon world that serves as a welcome contrast to the muted palettes of more realistic games. The soundtrack is similarly upbeat and peppy, and it features a main theme that will be stuck in my head for years.Another potential sticking point for some might be the relatively short length of the story. Clocking in at about three hours, it ends before the central conceit starts to wear thin. Dadliest Catch does about as much as it can with its octopus limb control scheme, but it (ironically) would not have the legs to last much longer. I personally had no issue with the length, but those who like to calculate hours of entertainment per dollar may take exception that the main story finishes not very long after it begins.Alleviating that a bit are some optional objectives for those who want to keep playing. Each level hides three custom neckties for Octodad to wear, each requiring thorough exploration, tricky climbing, or some interaction with the environment. Additionally, each level has a par time to beat, opening it up for potential speed running.Also included is Steam Workshop support, so users can create their own levels, and a hilarious cooperative mode that allows up to four players to control one or more limbs, requiring an unusual form of teamwork and resulting in an even more awkward octopus than usual. Despite the short length of the campaign, there is enough in place for diehard enthusiasts to keep going for as long as they want.In the end, I would not be surprised to hear that the Octodad community is thriving years down the road. It exudes a certain weirdness and charm that makes it stand out from a lot of other titles out there, and there are tools in place for it to live on past the point when the credits start to roll. Though it has some issues with frame rate drops and its approach to control is definitely not for everybody, Dadliest Catch kept a smile on my face for most of its duration.TL;DR: The long-awaited video game adaptation of The Dream of the Fisherman's Wife.

												Yes; I recommend this game but with a GIANT sidenote.The game is hilariously put together; many ifnot all the words spoken are a laugh and the many hidden jokes and gags make for an entertaining playthrough.The controls are fun to mess around with and even more chaotic once you get multiple people involved.It is however...way too short.In about 2 hours with faffing about you can complete the game; leaving only achievements, hidden ties and some other side things to do which is an incredible shame.I was surprised and sat in my chair waiting for the credits to stop rolling and take me further into the story ... but alas that was it.So take it as you will; Want a game that makes you laugh for an hour or two with friends then by all means go and get it.If you expect to be entertained longer then you're sadly mistaken.

												The best Octopus physics simulator out there. Its main game mechanic is player frustration so I wouldn't bother picking this up if you don't have a sense of humour and don't mind failing at simple tasks.The aim of the game is to control an octopus, pretending to be a normal dad as he does day to day tasks, without letting anyone realise you're actually an octopus, you can control each limb and have to move around the levels as best as you can, the controls can be a little awkward to say the least.Best played in co-op no doubt, roulette mode just adds that extra level of irritation as just when you think you and your friend have got the controls down and are starting to move well, control of each limb switches and you're back to square one.

content:
Posted: June 10, 2014
												I think that ths is a good game. It needs to be longer, but it's very polished and there have been no bugs that I have been able to find. I liked the ending. It was, without spoiling it, a traditional boss fight. The boss fight was hard which I, at the time found frustrating, but I am glad it was hard as it would have been an anticlimax otherwise. The implamentation of collectable ties was a good idea. In the future, it would be great to see some implamentation of a multiplayer. That would be quirky and cool though im unsure how it would work. A possibility for custom ties would be a nice addition, possibly adopting the tf2 ideology where you can obtain 'special' ties or hats etc, though I feel that this would only work well with a multiplayer version of the game. I think that the price of £15 may have been slightly too high seeing as the play-time was probably between 4 hours, though I understand that the quality of the game may have dropped if the business's costs were't covered. And besides, if they can produce a game this polished then they probably deserve to earn a good chunk of profit. After getting used to the controls, they were easy to use for what they were - this is obviously a well designed game. I would recomend this game to anyone who's looking for a casual, fun and creative game. Out of 10, I would rate this an 8/10, very good.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												I was expecting a Goat Simulator clone with this game but was pleasantly surprised that this ended up being a fun game. You play an octupus who is pretending to be human,who also has a family somehow. The levels in the game sees you trying to do simple everyday tasks while trying to avoid drawing to much attention so you aren't outed as being an octupus. This sounds easy enough but the catch is that each of Octodads limbs is controlled seperately and you have to co-ordinate each limb to complete your tasks. This is actually quite fun and trying to do things like mow the lawn while your falling about swinging a lawnmower as you go is a memorable experience. This game is surprisingly structured with a story and levels with various goals which is something i hadn't expected,as i had anticipated a sandbox type game similar to Goat Simulator. What really lets the game down is how short it is. You could easily finish this in a couple of hours which is a shame as it feels like they could have maybe packed in a few more levels. There is a range of mods that give limited replay value but the ones i did try i didn't play for very long.The Good:- fun light hearted casual game- levels are enjoyable and so is trying co-ordinate Octodad through seemingly simple tasksThe Bad:- very short  Overall this is a decent game and though it seems a silly premise i enjoyed it more than i thought. It's let down by how short it is and i really can't recommend buying this game at full price for that reason. If you like casual silly games then pick this up when it's on sales. If you hated games like Goat Simulator or Surgeon Simulator give this a miss. 6.5/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												Picked this game up on sale and it was a fun, if incredibly brief experience. It's qwop with aquatic life. Well, sort of anyway. Playing with a controller (which is recommended) the movement is controlled by the triggers acting as your legs and the sticks manuvering your right arm in order to solve various tasks. The issue that comes up with this control scheme though is that there's no reliable way to control the camera. You can use the d-pad to glance the camera in the direction you press, but it's not helpful. In fact the camera is probably one of the biggest reasons there's some conveyence problems with certain levels when trying to figure out what to do next. The movement in itself isn't as hard as it looks. There's a reasonable amount of lock on when picking up objects so that you don't have to be pinpoint accurate when picking up or placing objects and walking is fine if you just alternate the triggers. Where it gets annoying is when you have to make your way up stairs, ladders, or catwalks. The imprecise gangliness of your legs is one of the main jokes of the game, but it quickly becomes a pain when you have fallen off the ledge for the umpteenth time or move your legs too much and fall all the way down the ladder to where you started.The story is lacking in some explanation and real buildup resulting in a hasty conclusion. Octodad is a surprisingly emotive character though, and a joy to see blurb and react to situations. Though this is somewhat of a nitpick. This is a story in a game where an octopus is a father of a human family.TLDR: Very short, premise can get annoying in certain situations, but it's a cute and enjoyable game nonetheless. Pick it up on a sale.

												At first, i just couldn't see what it was people seemed to like about this game, it's just seemed to odd in it's whole concept and plot but first after completing it i realized why.You play as a normal everyday human dad, doing choores and taking care of his family, doing things like buy groceries, clean up the house, take care of your kids, mow the lawn. 												Score: 7.5 / 10Price/Value: $5Time: 3 HoursDifficulty: HardThis turned out to be a lot better than I had initially expected. Octodad has you playing as an octopus masquerading as an everyday human being. Comedy is what this title is all about as you aternate between tentacles for feet and arms to perform everyday tasks. The trick is to be as smooth and precise as possible so your family and other humans don't discover your horrifying secret. With only three hours of content I can't recommend this for higher than $5; but considering how often this title goes on sale it shouldn't be too difficult to nab it cheap.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												A very amusing and cute ragdoll physics game, in which you control a very wiggly octopus--er, I mean, NORMAL HUMAN BEING. The controls are very bizarre at first, but I found myself getting fairly comfortable with them after playing the game for a bit. While the main story and characters are funny and well done, some of the most amusing parts of the game are in the details; the game is peppered with witty references (seen in many of the products at the grocery store) and amusing details (the stained glass window in the church, and the identity of the "Best Man" at the wedding). For me, the game has two flaws to it. The first is that it's fairly short. I finished the main story the same day I bought the game. It does have some replay value through co-op and achievements, but it would have been nice if the game was a bit longer (or had bonus chapters, etc.). The second is that the camera angles get a little awkward. The camera adjusts itself based on where it is you are in a level, but I found it didn't always adjust accordingly if I tried to go back to an area (for example, I tried to go back into the kitchen in the second level once, but the camera refused to move past the doorway, so essentially couldn't go back inside without being completely blind). You can use the WASD keys to alter the camera slightly, but I didn't find this to be very helpful. Overall, I would recommend the game. Considering how short it is, however, I would recommend getting it while it's on sale instead of paying full price..Edit: I nominated this game for the Steam awards. Partially because I wanted to give it a shout-out, but mostly because I was too lazy to write a review for any of the other games I nominated.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 11, 2014
												Octodad looked like a very silly and unnecessary concept, and didn't seem like it'd be a game that you would get your money worth out of. I am here to say that I was surprisingly proven wrong when I decided to purchase Octodad. The original game was quirky and seemed to be just a joke...until they actually turned it into a full game. Octodad: Dadliest Catch is very much of a sleeper hit as was Papers, Please last year.Gameplay: Everything you do and interact with is physics based, which also includes walking around (or how others would call it, fumbling around.) It's a weird concept that turned out to be a fun-filled romp of slapping around into everything in the world plus stretching your appendages past the limits into other objects. All of what this game is rounded out to quite a bit of fun and laughs for others who watched me play it.Graphics: This game looks like something out of a Unity game that was made during Game Jam, with some other elements that would be in a AAA game. Some spots looked bland and boring, while others looked unique and dynamic. Don't pass the graphics up as a bad thing though, since it doesn't detract from the experience itself.Sound: Constant slapping around and sloshing of Octodad's tentacles reacting with objects as well as the world itself made for some laughs as it does sound rather inappropriate in nature. Nothing sounded out of place however, though there were rare times when sound clips did repeat a few times in succession.Story: Octodad starts out with him marrying the love of his life. As it progressed, the game introduced mystery elements that were left either empty or unanswered at the end. Lots of plot holes and never ended story parts made the story felt unfinished, but it did have its charming moments. If the story did have more of the questions I had answered, then it would have felt like more of a complete story after the last cutscene ended and the credits started rolling.Multiplayer: Local co-op consists of giving the other player(s) control of either the legs or arms of Octodad, depending of what is chosen in the menu. Up to four players can play, having one person use either one arm or one leg. If I ever do get to try out the co-op, then I will update my review with my thoughts on this gameplay option.Overall, Octodad will most likely be in my Top 10 for 2014 due to the charming nature of the story plus the fun and addicting nature of fumbling around trying to control the character. Pick it up if you want several hours of fun and laughs, or a time waster.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 19, 2015
												What an interesting little game. When I say "little" game, though, I do mean that. If you are relatively decent at the game, then you can probably beat it in 2 hours, or even less. The only thing that really extends the game time is collecting the Ties, which are hidden collectibles, and that becomes more annoying than fun in the later levels.Octodad is simply an extended mini-game. Technically, I've played it 3 times in order to collect all of the achievements. I actually was able to run through all of the levels on my 3rd playthrough in less than 40 minutes. Most of the levels in the game are short, though the first time playing the game will extend that time because of the amount of work that is needed to get used to the game's controls.Certainly, if you are someone to get mad over small things in video games, you might not find this game fun. The game is intentionally annoying and difficult with its controls. It will take you a while to get used to them, and even then, you're never really going to be perfect with them. Besides the controls themselves, the gameplay is nothing too special. Most of the "puzzles" are simply to run or climb somewhere, grabbing items along the way. Only a few places have unique puzzles, which are essentially the three sub-areas inside of the aquarium that you visit.But the game still holds onto its fun style of gameplay because it isn't too long. In fact, I think the shortness of the game is good. Otherwise, if the game was several hours of the same types of puzzles, it would lose its appeal.Besides the gameplay, the graphics are pretty colorful, and the humor of the game certainly is silly but funny. I enjoy Octodad's "conversations" and it is hilarious how people don't see him for what he is. In some senses, the hilarity of that is the entire game, but I also think there is validity to people's claims that there is a more serious undertone to the game. Octodad certainly feels out of place, as if his being an octopus is something that is ruining his life. And some people have brought up relevance to people with certain disorders or illnesses that alienate them in society, and it is definitely something similar in sadness. Whether the developers were thinking in an analagous manner or not, I don't know.I did not pay full price for Octodad, and I probably suggest not to, because it really annoys me when I buy games and finish them really quickly. There's nothing exactly groundbreaking about Octodad, but it is something fresh. At the same time, it is short-lived, and as I said, it would have lost its appeal if they made it much longer without adding something new.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2014
												It's hard to explain exactly what this game is. You're a dad in a (mostly) normal American suburb, trying to live your life and help your family. Also you're an octopus, so that makes things a bit more complicated.I guess it's a third-person puzzle game? Maybe? But it's less figuring out what you need to do, and more figuring out how to use the abilities you have to do what you know you need to. It's difficult to explain. It requires the same sort of brain-rewriting and mechanics-unlearning that you went through when you started to get the hang of Surgeon Simulator.It's weird. It's funny. Most importantly, it's different. I really think anyone and everyone should try it out. It's worth it.

												Here is the main just of this game:It is about a young man who joins the army in search for fame and glory and then BOOM he hits the fan and pretty much gets shot up and takin as a prisoner in war. His old war buddy Jonny soap is like "yo" and shoots the nazis in the face and then boom another shot goes off and hitler is bye bye. The young man comes back home as a grown man. He finds that the world around him is not what it seems, it changed very much very. So. This. Is. His. Story. He then tries to find his friend Soap but ends up only finding his left leg limb infront of hitlers house. So he then devotes his life to killing people with his left limb. later that day he found a bullet in the ground from digging for gold to pay his rent. he takes that bullet to the CIA department of bullet tracing technology and finds taht it was hitlers bullet all along. this means... hitler killed himself. So he finds out johnny is actually allive. this stuns him and makes him go in acoma. he wakes up in a zombie apocolypse alone. he makes his way out of the bloody horrifying hospital to only find that his wife and son went to atlanta to survive. he makes it there after meeting tyrone jamalkins and his son donavinn. he then sees soap.. his old partner in war and soap took his wife, clarise. so he then kills soap on a farm and the zombies like die. he then goes back to his life but doesnt make any more money. so then he sees that his brother-in-law busts meth dealers that make fat stacks of cheese (implying $$$). so then he becomes a meth cook and changes his name to heisenpus. from then he goes on meeting drug lords and like having a really good story and all. from there he then kills like a ton of people with a gun and is sent to the shadow deef. he then is there for 12 years and has to live off of pooping in a bucket and some soup. a priest helps him escape but dies in the process so it kinda sucks. once he makes it out he gets his revenge on everyone who betrays him. He then leads the scottish army against the british to save his humanity but then is almost dead. Now from here he then gets invited to join the 'Thield' and be part of the 'Bavengers'. He then falls down into a nuclear reacted tank of lemonade that turns him into an octopus. This is very tragic in his life. very.very.trangic. from then he becomes an octopus taking on his old name as a meth cook heisenpus. He seeks to remarry his old wife who thinks he is like long gone because he was really cool. this is where it leaves off and know you play an octopus who acts like a human to get his old life back. Have fun.

content:
Posted: July 31, 2014
												I've sunk to a whole new low. I bought Octodad, and am not completely dissapointed. Do I regret paying $5 for it? Of course, but I have to say, this game had some good things going for it. The main theme song was actually very funny. It was made to sound like a very cheap, very bad song, and I thought it fit very well into the game. Sadly, besides that song, the rest of the soundtrack was awful. Another really funny thing in the game was the opening credits. You got to destroy things, fall from the sky, and listen to the great theme song, obviously a great combination. Another pretty good thing about the game was the fact that its jokes usually made me laugh a bit. While that may sound really good, you need to know t hat none of the jokes were really funny, they were just pretty good. Still, the funny video game and youtuber easter eggs, along with a lot of the conversations you are a part of and overhear (your kids are the funniest) make for some good laughs. Speaking of conversations, the voice acting was better than expected. The kids sound like, well, kids, and what they say and do remind me of some I know. Also, your wife does a pretty good job of conveying emotions when she talks. One more thing that I think you could call good would have to be the story. There were a lot of plot holes, but I get the feeling some of them were there to enhance the silliness. Also, I must say, this game had a decent story, and that was WAY better than what I thought. Still, the chef (antagonist) had no real motive, he just starts being a jerk the first time you meet him. Also, there was a flashback that seemed like the present to me, and it took until the ending cutscene of that level for me to realize that it was in the past. If you are basing your purchase entirely from this review, so far it would probably look like a good buy, and that's because I haven't said the negatives. The game is VERY short, 5 hours in total, and although you can play community levels, it still seems like we aren't really getting enough meat on the bone. Last but not least, the gameplay was AWFUL! I know the controls were meant to be funny, but it got in the way a lot and caused me to die or get caught quite a few times. It turned a lot of fun parts into a grind, and kind of ruined the last half of the game in my opinion. Would I recommend this? I am honestly on the fence, because I think it is something worth experiencing, but it's something that you can get the full experience from by watching a let's play. Still, if you're like me and would never watch a full let's play, it might be worth getting on sale like I did. I think this series has potential to be a lot better, but for now, this is what we get. If I had to give it a score, I'd give it a 6/10. Pretty much a lot of fun and games ruined by terrible gameplay, and cut abruptly short.

content:
Posted: October 17, 2016
												Instead of listing everything I love about this game, I'm trying a different approach. There's just too many interesting and original gameplay moments. To be clear; the game is an absolute classic. It should be in everyone's Steam Library."Who's that man with the three piece suit? Makin' a doll with a log and fruit? Who's that man with the eight strong legs? Tried to make me breakfast but he broke my eggs? Octodad - nobody suspects a thing. Octodad - he's got a good thing going. Octodad - nobody suspects a thing. Octodad - Octodad. Who's that man with the hard, hard beak? three feet tall, with a soft physique? How's a man like that man feel? running for his life from a moray eel? Octodad - nobody suspects a thing. Octodad - he's got a good thing going. Octodad - nobody suspects a thing. Octodad - Octodad."

content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
												In octodad, you're an octopus smashing in a wacky physics simulator, while trying to do something as hard as serving tea or buying stuff. Yeah, that's stupid. Yes you're the only octpus married to a whomen, and no one know it. Yeah you have kids and you'll nevever want to see how you get them. That's stupid and you'll definitively need a bad sense of humour to like this game, but if you have it, it's terribly fun.The best part of this game is the 2 players mode, that makes octodad the best drunken-party game ever. Each player controls random tentacles and they have to cooperate to do things. It never works, you'll want to kill your partner, and that's the purpose of this game. You'll probably never finish the 1st level but you'll laugh so much that you'll never care.And of course... controls are horrible!The should I buy algorithm.if(serious)then{don't buy it}if(not stupid) then {don't buy it}if(high)then{buy it, then ridde a unicorn}if(sober and have friends)then{buy it, have fun}if(sober and alone){buy it, smile, then be desperate, go out, meet friends, play octodad, goto previous line}

But they fail to notice the steam workshop that this game has, For now it only contains few items. But after a while I'm sure people will bring HOURS of new and fun content to the game. Trying to find and collect all the different ties (without a walkthrough) will probably add another hour to the game.The game's worth shouldn't also be calculated by length, It has a nice story and some cool mechanics. Of course the controls are sometimes a pain to handle (but you're an octopus, that's what it's all about).

content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
												A game where the humor comes from both the mechanics and storytelling. On the surface, this game may seem like a classic piece YouTuber bait, with it's quirky control scheme, unusual characters, abundance of physics items, and an unbelievable plot  to top it all off, but deeper down, this game tells the story of love, loss, and acceptance. It is the classic tale of the perfect suburban family with a deep dark secret.Is Octodad an octupus?Will Scarlet ever learn true inter-species love?How were the children concieved?This game, with its fun mechaincs and hilarious stories, strives to answer those questions and with them, attempts to reconcile for man's most primordial fear: calamari.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 2, 2016
												I was inspired to buy this game, after watching TotalBiscuit and his wife play the game. When they played it, they had a blast and it was hilarious to watch.After buying the game myself and playing it with a friend as local co-op I have to say that I did not enjoy it. The gameworld and its humor are adorable and the concept of chaotic controls are very interesting, but in co-op it needs to persons who are able to roleplay and immerse themselves in the role of the Octodad. Without this the game is bland and the gameplay repetitive for menial tasks. Another huge disappointment for me was how the co-op was implemented.Without a controller no co-op is possible at all! Even if you have one available, like I did, the controls are unevenly distributed, with one player controlling three limbs with the controller and the other using the mouse to control only one single arm.This takes away the most fun of the control scheme, as there is no chaos ensuing between the two players.I am severely dissatisfied that this was not communicated.So unless you own a controller for each person who wants to play, who are all willing to immerse themselves in roleplay and you really don't care about the money you will spend on this game, I will say not recommended.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Octodad: Dadliest CatchA Charming Game About a Normal Human Man.Developer: Young HorsesYear: 2014Genre: Indie, Comedy, AdventureFranchise: OctodadEngine: IrrlichtTL;DROctodad: DC is a thoroughly charming, well polished sequel to the thoroughly charming but far less polished 2010 student project Octodad. It retains the same goofy sense of humour and varied gameplay of the original but with a freshly revamped 50s art style and a more ambitious story. Play the original- available for free- before making the investment in this one. If you like that, you'll like this.REVIEWStory:When I first saw this game I thought that it would be more of the same Goat Sim/Amazing Frog/I am Bread♥♥♥♥♥♥♥  I avoided the purchase until I found it in an already inticing Humble Bundle. I booted it up to see if I could get a few chuckles out of it. What I found was a tight bundle of sharp writing, smart jokes and funny performances, with the "lol so floppy" humour serving as a anchor for some genuinely clever humour, rather than an obstacle to it. A particularly nice touch is the inclusion of two free DLC missions; one set in a hospital and one set in a restaurant. The former is delightfully narrated by Octodad's kids. The writing's no masterwork, but it's fun. A lot of it. 7.5/10Graphics:The janky,♥♥♥♥♥♥coloured visuals of the previous game are replaced with a slick, fluid colourful 50s soapbox style that give delightful motion to Octodad's suspiciously tentacle-like limbs. The environments feel authentic as you venture out of the house into the Everytown, USA town in which Octodad dwells. From the Edu-tainment utopia of the World of Kelp to the reference-packed Gervason's grocery store (Anyone for a rousing game of Sturgeon Simulator?) everywhere feels complete and fun to explore. 8/10Gameplay:You may have noticed my distaste for Surgeon Simulator and it's ilk. However, I am a huge fan of Octodad, Overcooked and even Who's Your Daddy. This is because the latter games know how to handle the funny dynamic of normal problems with weird solutions. Surgeon Simulator is a weird problem with a weird solution. No contrast, no humour. If I were to purchase juice or make soup in real life it would be easy. Seeing all the steps required for Octodad to do this sort of simple task is funny. Having to climb up a tower of soda to get juice is the normal mixed with the absurd, not just the absurd. This, in tandem with the smart writing elevates this game from the typical surrealist "xD he is octopus" fare that can be found for a dime a dozen on Steam. The gameplay is varied, challenging and, once again, fun. The only point where the game fell apart was at the end, where the normality was removed and replaced with a boss fight so generic and unsatisfying that it may as well be picked off of a store shelf. With that said, it's easy to do, so it's short. 8/10Overall:While this game may be short and a tad pricey, don't be fooled by it's outward appearance. Great visuals, funny writing and solid gameplay meld with a charming soundtrack to make a game that's certainly worth your time. 7.5/10Check out my profile for my review policy and thanks for reading.Til my next review!

content:
Posted: October 3, 2015
												One of the first games I got on my steam account, and definitely one of the great ones. This is another one of the gimick-based indie games that were popular around that time and still are, except this one really does something that makes it feel very unique. Something I seemed to notice with gimmick-y games are that they're pretty much revolved around a couple of achievements and experiencing all the fun, wacky zany gameplay it has to offer; now, this game does have that, but it's so refined and well done it's consistently interesting the whole game. It has a silly but somewhat emotional storyline that really is a lot of fun to play, and is consistantly interesting. Along with that 5 hour story, you have about 30 achievements that make this game even more fun and replayable, and gives the game a good exit.Verdict: A really good game, going beyond gimmicks and actually making a fun story. There's not reason not to get it, so why not do it?

number of helpful: 7 of 14 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 13, 2014
												The premise is what makes the game stick out most: you play as an octopus who is disguised as your stereotypical suburban dad. Remaining unsuspected is the point of the whole game, but of course that goal is complicated by the control scheme. In some ways it is reminiscent of Surgeon Simulator 2013, but with more ragdoll physics. When you are controlling one of Octodad's limbs you really only have control over the tip of that limb; the rest of the limb and the rest of his body will flop around wherever they feel like. The only exception is that his feet remain planted most of the time.Much of the game involves Octodad attempting to carry out everyday tasks, such as making breakfast, mowing the lawn, and shopping for groceries. There is a "suspicion meter" that goes up when people witness you do particularly clumsy things. It is extremely difficult to lose this way though, which makes the game even more absurd.The larger threat is a sushi chef who appears to be the only person around who realises that Octodad is not what he pretends to be. He appears from time to time to try to expose or kill Octodad. When you consider that every other character is white and the chef is a pretty terrible caricature of a Japanese chef, the game seems incredibly racist.Polygon had an interesting article[www.polygon.com] about how Octodad can be considered a metaphor for those of us who live our lives concealing something from even those who are closest to us. Most people wouldn't think of this though, especially kids like my sister who would just be delighted by the slapstick comedy.There were some extremely frustrating segments, such as going up some down escalators and running away from the chef while trying to perform other tasks. If you are easily frustrated, I wouldn't recommend Octodad.The game was short, coming in at about two hours for my first playthrough. The only reason I can think of to replay it would be to try the coop mode, where up to four people control his various limbs. They also wisely included support for user-created maps. I've pretty much had my fill of the game though, so I probably won't try many of those.My recommendation would be that you go and play the original student project[www.octodadgame.com] and if you really want more Octodad then you can go and get Dadliest Catch. I still wouldn't pay more than $10 on it though.

												I'm not quite sure how to review this so:Pros:* The humor is quite well done (IMHO).* The concept is certainly unique* It can, at times, even be fun.Cons:* The game is basically a one-trick pony: try to control Octodad and fail repeatedly.So far, I have gotten to the aquarium and have spent way more time than I'd like to admit trying to maneuver Octodad up 2 sets of wrong-way escalators. content:
Posted: August 29, 2014
												The gameplay is fun. It's basically what if "Surgeon Simulator 2013" were an actual game where its utterly broken mechanics were featured in a way that makes sense in universe - you being an octopus and all. Of course the controls are the reason why you're here so complaining that they suck is missing the point. This does however not take away from the fact that certain sections are just needlessly annoying to traverse. And I really have to say that 2 hours for $15 is just too short. I get that this joke would've become old quite quickly, so instead of demanding more I demand a price reduction. I'm not even sure the $5 I spent during the last summer sale were justified for those 2 hours, but I would've felt ripped off at three times that.If you can find it on sale it's definitely worth checking out, insofar as you haven't watched any of the oh so funny youtube personalities play it for the lulz. If you have, don't bother, the humor is spoiled for you. You may find enjoyment out of the controls but honestly I'm not sure I can recommend it, it's just a bit too unsubstantial.

												This is one of the few times I'm happy a game was super short. Took me two hours to beat the game and at one point I went to make and eat lunch for about fifteen minutes. The controls are the most frustrating thing ever created, I understand this is the gimmick of the game but it's completely uncontrolable. The last mission was terrible, constantly falling into fire because the beam has no foot room, only to be brought back to the other side of the room. The final fight was terrible as well, the fish balloons that you need to use are half the time impossible to pick up. The character would pick up any object but the balloon, just because of this it took me fifteen tries too many.The game is cute and the music is good but it falls flat almost everywhere else. Not worth a fifteen dollar price tag, nor the summer sale price I got it for.

content:
Posted: July 18, 2014
												Octodad... it's very debatable, let's say that. In my honest-to-God opinion that I am very entitled to for having played it even this much, I will tell you that it is quite... different. Pros: Very unique and never-before-seen concept with a charming though short plot with lots of laughs and goofy gameplay. Cons: Awful controls, lack of inspiration and devotion in the workshop, difficult to play, not enjoyable in general due to the extremely repetitive nature of the game and lack of much additional content and very little likelihood to replay after the first playthrough, assuming you just don't uninstall the game. It's frustrating and funny, but overall this is actually the only game I can ever recall buying and not liking, and I do not have a high standard for games in any way shape or form. Buy it at your own discretion.

content:
Posted: August 1, 2014
												Octodad: Dadliest Catch is a wonderful game in my opinion for a handful of reasons and I will cover all of them in this review Storyline length and quality: a common complaint is that the story is short, while i agree with this I also don't really mind the game takes about 2 hours to run through if you don't waste time and run through the game but if you take your time to do what you feel like doing and explore every bit of floppy chaos in a level the game's play time can go up to at least 5 hours. The story itself feels like a movie or a book it's really just wonderful and sort of unique but extremely cliche at the same time without spoiling anything here's the jist of it: you play as octodad an octopus whose family and the rest of humankind (except for a single sushi chef) thinks he's a man just carrying out his daily life.Gameplay/Controls:The gameplay is great and by that i mean the physics are generally pretty good i haven't had anything get stuck in a wall or under a table or whatever. the controls on the other hand are different at first they are kind of hard but after some practice you'll be jiggling around like a pro. it really only took me about 10 minutes to get the controls down but after that it was smooth sailing.Maps:The maps are great they have plenty of props to play with but also AREN'T overflowing with props because that would make it hard to move. most maps have secret areas where you can collect ties which i will get to later.Collectibles:the one thing that annoys me the MOST in games is upgradable skill systems that you need to use to beat the game, octodad on the other hand doesn't have one which makes me VERY happy you can play through without having to spend EXP to get new skills because there are no skill points in-game anyway. the only collectible is ties which are just new ties to wear and look cool.graphics:I have a toaster and can run this at 100 FPS. 'nuff said.Workshop support/Replay value:IMMENSE REPLAY VALUE the game has SO MUCH to do in every level that you really need to replay it at least twice to get all the content in. not to mention this game has workshop support and my overall experience with it: walked into a supermarket naked and stole cereal from a lady.          10/10 for workshop.OVERALL GRADE: 9.5/10 reason for not a perfect 10: workshop has skins for octodad but they have to be installed manually but it's not a big deal.

content:
Posted: February 2, 2014
												I can't tell you how much I enjoyed this game, good lord. It's so cute and funny and has a lot of love to it, it's just everything a video game should be. My only complaints are some of the dumb memes in the supermarket level and that the final section felt a little janky and badly designed to me. It's also a pretty short game, which might turn you off, but it's a perfect length in my eyes--it doesn't overstay its welcome and does just about everything it could with its gameplay. It lasts just lost enough to be satisfying.Basically Octodad made me really happy. I'm amazed at how this comedy octopus man is a better dad than most real dads I know.

content:
Posted: May 29, 2014
												If you're looking for a totally unique game experience, look no further than Octodad: Dadliest Catch. The game mostly resolves around trying to complete everyday tasks, but with a twist - you're an octopus pretending to be a human dad! There are many hilarious and frustrating in-game moments, hell, even walking can be a chore at times. All in all, this is definitely a game worth playing if you're looking for something new.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
												Octodad is a one of a kind.  It is witty, charming, funny, and most importanly unique.  Although controls can be difficult at times, that is kind of the point.  It is not suppose to be easy to handle.  Your objective is to act like a human while having tentacles as legs and arms, thus making it difficult to navigate.  After about thirty minutes or so, you should have a grasp of your character and will be able to handle the more difficult objectives.       Young Horses does a great job at making everyday situations into a comedy.  If you are looking for something new, check this game out.

												"Octodad, nobody suspects a thing" sums things up pretty well. This game is very short (about an hour long) so you should probably wait for the price to go down to around $7.49. Other than that this game was loads of fun. It puts you in different areas with different tasks to complete with the Aquarium being the largest. It has lots of activities to do and almost all of them are challenging. The ending of the game is funny and the rest of the game is very enjoyable. 8/10

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 1, 2014
												Octodad is silly, fun, and annoying at the same time. The controls are wacky, but it adds to the enjoyment of going around as an octopus. However, when the game gets more challenging later on, the controls start to get annoying, especially in the boss battle. If you can master the controls (unlikely), this game is going to be short for you. However, the real gems here are the costum courses in the Steam Workshop. That feature is the games redeeming factor. There's enjoyment to be found here, but for the main price of $15, you're probably better off waiting for this to go on sale.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												HP LOVE CRAFTS MOST MISSOING ROMANTIC CALL OF CATHLUGHUTT NOVEL EVER. THIS WAS THE MISSING LINK HP LOCECRAFTS FANS HAVE BEEN MISSING FOR THE LAST CENTURY. ITS FILLED WITH BOTH COMEDY, CUTNESS AND ROAMNCE. HAVE EVER THOUGHT OF HOW CTHLUHS MINIONS TRIED TO FIT IN THE WORLD OF BLIND PEOPLE. WELL NOW YOU GET TO FIND OUT, PUT ON A SUIT AND MARRY A WIFE AND HAVE KIDS WITH HER. SHE DOESNT NEED TO KNOW YOU ARE A OCTOPUSS (use any refrence here, rapiist, serial killer, terrorist) ITS COMPLETLY OKAY TO HID THINGS FROM YOUR WIFE AND KIDS FOR SO MANY YEARS. THE GAME THEN STARTS YOU OUT OF HOW DIFFICULT IT IS TO FIT INTO A WORLD OF NORMAL BORING PEOPLE, THIS IS WHY WE PLAY VIDEO GAMES, ALSO WHY I LIE TO MY WIFE. IT WAS THEN I HAD REALIZED THAT WITHOUT MY WIFE AND KIDS I WAS NOTHING, A DEEP MAN IN THE DEEP OCEAN. THATS WHAT OCTO DAD MADE ME SEE. IT MADE ME SEE THAT NO MATTER WHAT I AM, I WILL ALWAYS BELOVED. THE ONE THING PEOPLE HAE FORGOTEN IN THIS WORLD IS LOVE, AND HOW MUCH BIG IT IS. AND I HAVE ALSO FORGOTEEN OF HOW GOOD SUSHI TASTES TOO!

content:
Posted: February 13, 2014
												Octodad manages to turn what would seem like infuriating, clumsy control mechanics into a remarkably hilarious game with its dialog, aesthetic and silly premise.Trying to execute the simplest tasks often results in a calamity of fail that you can't help but laugh your way through. Unlike other games with purposefully difficult controls, this game pulls it off without the player feeling completely frustrated by turning the gimmick into half the fun.The animations are fluid and the overall design gels well with the story and characters to create the vibrant world Octodad struggles with so hard each day.Definitely worth the buy. Support creative games like these so we'll see more of them :)

												HP LOVE CRAFTS MOST MISSOING ROMANTIC CALL OF CATHLUGHUTT NOVEL EVER. THIS WAS THE MISSING LINK HP LOCECRAFTS FANS HAVE BEEN MISSING FOR THE LAST CENTURY. ITS FILLED WITH BOTH COMEDY, CUTNESS AND ROAMNCE. HAVE EVER THOUGHT OF HOW CTHLUHS MINIONS TRIED TO FIT IN THE WORLD OF BLIND PEOPLE. WELL NOW YOU GET TO FIND OUT, PUT ON A SUIT AND MARRY A WIFE AND HAVE KIDS WITH HER. SHE DOESNT NEED TO KNOW YOU ARE A OCTOPUSS (use any refrence here, rapiist, serial killer, terrorist) ITS COMPLETLY OKAY TO HID THINGS FROM YOUR WIFE AND KIDS FOR SO MANY YEARS. THE GAME THEN STARTS YOU OUT OF HOW DIFFICULT IT IS TO FIT INTO A WORLD OF NORMAL BORING PEOPLE, THIS IS WHY WE PLAY VIDEO GAMES, ALSO WHY I LIE TO MY WIFE. IT WAS THEN I HAD REALIZED THAT WITHOUT MY WIFE AND KIDS I WAS NOTHING, A DEEP MAN IN THE DEEP OCEAN. THATS WHAT OCTO DAD MADE ME SEE. IT MADE ME SEE THAT NO MATTER WHAT I AM, I WILL ALWAYS BELOVED. THE ONE THING PEOPLE HAE FORGOTEN IN THIS WORLD IS LOVE, AND HOW MUCH BIG IT IS. AND I HAVE ALSO FORGOTEEN OF HOW GOOD SUSHI TASTES TOO!

Posted: January 31, 2014
												This game is freaking amazing and is super fun. Had to get used to the controls but after the ending I got used to the controls and was able to put that to the test with playing the workshop levels. What I mean by this is that the game is too short. I only spent 4 hours going as slow as I possibly could around the levels and it was still too short. Besides the workshop that has a lack of levels at this moment in time and will have me very busy when more levels come out, there needs to be more stuff coming from the developers for the story or maybe something new entirely other than the story. I still think it was worth the $12 but being that the game is so short, I am starting to think otherwise.

Posted: September 6, 2015
												So much fun!  I had a blast playing this one and it's even more fun to watch when you're not struggling with the controls.You will struggle with the controls, especially with a controller -- which is the only way to play it.  It's a marvelous challenge, and unbelievably satisfying once you get him to do what you want, in some semblance of the way you intend.  The side-effects of the controls is an incredibly silly experience.  You will spill things, flip tables, and bonk unsuspectings. I recommend this game to everyone and anyone who wants something different.

number of helpful: 5 of 12 people (42%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
												A really entertaining and unique game, I really enjoyed it; But it was so short! The game can be completed in less than an hour and is not all that complicated. The mechanics of the games character are awesome, I just wish they would have done more with it. By the time you start to enjoy the game it's over and there isn't much replay value to be had. The levels and puzzles are really simple and require next to no thought.Don't get me wrong I love the game, but I can't recommend it at the current price. For a game that can be completed in less than an hour, $15 is a little steep. The least they could have done to make it worth while is package the original Octodad project with it, or add in those levels in with the new character mechanics.

Posted: June 12, 2014
												I got it on sale for like eight quid, got three hours gameplay, still not worth it, plus its painful to play not 'cause like the console version, that has harder controls so its funny to move around, no, painful that its so easy to move you realise that the game is flawed in so many ways, e.g getting a bottle of drink from a tower you have to climb, I swear to God, the game, even if I was careful with the easy controls, kept "slipping" my foot off the side of the tower, but not only that, my other leg randomly moved away and I fell to the floor! WTF! People who say it's part of the charm are crazy, the game is purposely holding you back, which isn't why I bought it, I liked the struggling movements of the console version, but this? No, just no. It's a rip off, if you get it for a quid, fine, but anything above that? Nah, save it. 1/6 (haha, get it? Octodad's only got 6 tentacles, I think)

content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
												This is silly fun, and has a great musical theme (god, It will be hard to forget the Octodad song). The controls are intentionally awful, and while it's funny to watch at first, the joke gets old after the first couple of minutes. It's a good game and it does what it promises well, but for me, It's not worth the asking price. I'd only buy it again if it was on a sale for a VERY low price.

number of helpful: 29 of 61 people (48%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 1, 2014
												Pros: The wonky controls are back from the original. The story and characters are funny enough. Steam Workshop support.Cons: The game is far too short, the story can be completed in 2 hours. Introduces some annoying mechanics like stealth and segments where you have to run for your dear life. Octodad's limbs can get stuck sometimes by clipping into objects.Honestly, 2 hours for $15 is a bit too much to ask. I feel like the  devs could have made a much bigger game, but then ran out of ideas midway and cut things short. The modders could potentially revitalize the game if there's enough interest. This game had so much potential but fell short.

												Pros: It's charming as all get-out, the controls work pretty well, and it's well optimized and unified in its design and compatibility.Cons: It's an hour and a half long, and the last couple levels are a bunch of forced instant-fail stealth and action sequences that demand a somewhat unreasonable level of precision from a game deliberately designed around wonky controls and physics.I liked it overall, it's hard not to. It's just kind of short and flawed.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
												If you are into absurd humor this is your game.  It is quite delightful and places you as a regular suburban dad doing regular things only you are secretly an Octopus.  Just be prepared going into it that many of the things that give it charm and comedic value can also cause frustration.  Controls are intentionally awkward because you are an Octopus trying to be human.  You will not be able to navigate yourself in a dignified way and you will knock over just about everything in your way.   This wouldn't be such a big deal if this were an adventure game but the controls are so non-intuitive and strange the traditional "gamier" parts of it can easily become frustrating.  It is short but its just the right length to not get overly tired with the mechanics.  It's a few hour experience not an epic open world rpg and I was glad it was over when I saw the credits roll.
