content:
Posted: March 26, 2014
												This game is really, really good, but it isn't for everyone. The first thing to address here is the movement and controls. It's awkward, but calling it 'deliberately bad' is IMO not really true. It's responsive and precise, but the difficulty comes from the fact that you are an invertebrate rather than that the controls suck. The plot is nothing special, though it did carry more emotional weight than I thought it would. Graphics and voice acting is nothing special, but where the game really shines is it's sense of humour. Most of the reference based jokes are delivered via background objects so as not to confuse people who don't get them, and the chatter from passersby is something I genuinely want to listen to, as it always brings out a smile on my face. However, the gameplay is where this thing really shines. While it doesn't have that much replay value (the game's around 5 hours long assuming you don't rush through all the levels), there are decently hidden secrets to find and loads of little trinkets to grab and mess around with in your environment or just extra stuff to do, though there could potentially be more. Still, this game is just about having stupid fun and messing around, as the gameplay perfectly demonstrates. It composes of you doing ordinary mundane things at the start extremely awkwardly, and ends with you doing out of the ordinary things in ways you couldn't imagine. If you have low amounts of patience or are short on cash and therefore want a timesink, this isn't your game, but this is a nice diversion of a game. It also has Workshop support and a decent supply of nice quality user created levels (as well as some stuff done by the devs demonstrating what can be done in the engine). If you have your doubts you can always download the original Octodad for free and see if the control scheme agrees with you, and honestly, you probably know already if this is a game that you're going to enjoy.In conclusion, this is a game that is designed for people who just like doing stupid things in a game and laughing at it. It doesn't just rely on it's physics engine or controls as some reviews might imply, as it also has an fantastic sense of humour, good music and just an all-round good feel to it. Like I said, you should know if you will enjoy this or hate it. Also, they changed the stealth segments significantly and they now barely involve stealth at all, so you needn't worry about that. And if that isn't enough for you, the devs are planning to port the game to the PS4 with new levels and features and then update the PC version with said bonus goodies! My advice is get your tentacles on this game as soon as possible!

number of helpful: 2 of 7 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2014
												Octodad Dadliest Catch is an odd game: Octodad is about an octopus desperately trying to keep it together while he galumphs out the American Dream and be the best father that he can be. Every attempt to accomplish his role within the nuclear family drips with slapstick, pathos and even an unbearably affecting bravery in spots which smartly breaks up the comedy. In game terms, it’s little more than a tech demo fully realized. But on those same terms it’s a game which is feel-good throughout. The game’s controls has you controlling six cephalopod limbs of Octodad’s to walk and fill our your suit while the other two are used to interact with objects in the environment. As you seek to make yourself seem normal to your family and the outside world you do so typically by failing in comically abnormal ways. That’s the beauty of the game, even when you fail it’s more often than not more hilarious than when you succeed. The game also performs well as a cooperative game with children and adults alike. My niece particularly loved every moment she had with the game, and you can tell with how the game was structured that children were an aim more of the developers than most independent games currently on the market.That said the back third of the game is inconsistent with the gameplay of the rest of the game. While true, I much prefer the switch in difficulty and objectives. Through it’s rise in difficulty and reliance on mechanics, these previously trifle aspects of the game were now poignant to the story. The game gives you a reason to have skin in the game, which makes the inevitable compassionate ending that much more meaningful. I never stopped smiling throughout the four hours I played this game. I'll conclude by saying enjoy this game level by level, since there are definite pleasures along the way.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2014
												Short 3-Hour game, you're an octopus with a family, everyone thinks you're human because of the suit you wear - game has some funnies in it, but I didn't find it hilarious as some claim it to be. Controls are a bit more better than QWERTY's, but still a bit difficult to maintain. **SPOILER** In the end, for some reason, no one knew you were an octopus except for your daughter and the chef - there was no explaination to that at all. What seemed to be a super happy family, with a super happy wife - when she becomes upset with you for not ever having an adult-adult conversation, it just seems out of place.Out of all the games I didn't pirate before I bought - I wish I had done that for this one. Honestly, I think the game was just hyped up by the indie gaming community. I want my money back!

												I beat this game in less than 2 hours. Done. Over. Finshed. $16CAN!? No, thanks.This game is really fun, but it's like a book. You buy it and finish it. Done. Over. You can read it over again, but usually it's not that much fun or worth your while after the first time. You get to plop around as an octopus and do everyday things, which is nice. My only problem is a big one: you pay so much money for 2-4 hours of gameplay that gets old once you beat this game. Only buy it on a ~75% off sale.

												Slapstick funny for the first half hour, then a bit tedious as the story kind of dissolves and ends WAY too quickly. content:
Posted: August 22, 2016
												First, I laughed like crazy because the game was so ridiculous. Then, after playing for a while, I got really sad, because I drew an analogy with feelings of inadequacy, not fitting, being awkward at everything you doing, and even depression. And everyone around you thinks that everything is fine with you, you just not trying hard enough, or being silly. No understanding or compassion whatsoever. I thought "wow, the game is deep". But then, after spending some precious time in the aquarium, I got mad at the game, because hey, they a bit overdid this "life is hard" thing. Was I, as a player, supposed to start hating the game and every single stupid character in it?.. Well, anyway, I did.

number of helpful: 0 of 6 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 25, 2014
												This game reminds me of The Last of Us.Great story full of pathos.Great atmosphere that pulls you in.TERRIBLE gameplay.This game's controls are "meant" to be terrible.  It is all about controlling an object in 3D space with only a 2D control method.It is all a joke.  A joke that lasts 2 the hour runtime of the game.  Of course, the game maybe only has about an hour to an hour and a half of actual gamplay, but you will be constantly having to repeat sections due to the poor controls so that gets inflated slightly.Workshop support is fine and dandy, but the ONLY pull of this game is the charming story and characters.  Sure there is the joke of the controls, but that novelty ends right around the time you get to your Kitchen in the first level.  The reason you stick through the game past the first 10 minutes is because you actually end up feeling for the protagonist and his family.  There is no such story in the workshop missions so it is doubtful they will have the same impact as the rest of the game.This game is a definite pass at $15A "maybe" purchase at $10 because you basically get a nice, quirky, feature-length, semi-playable movie.Go for it at any price lower than $5Then again, what do you care what I have to say?  I know for a fact that you are just looking for games to pad out your backlog and this game will do just fine sitting unplayed in your Steam library.I would strongly suggest for Young Horses to fire their programers and move into making animated shorts full time.   Storytelling is what they are good at, making games is something they are not built for.

												I bought this game thinking it would be fun. Don't get me wrong - it was! For around 40 minutes. That's the problem. The gimmick grow tiresome just as the game starts introducing stealth and precision levels which with the controls that you are given are pure trial and error. Furthermore, it's all over in a pinch, with no replay value whatsoever (you can collect Octodad's ties in each level). For £10 I excpected a bit more. Do not recommend.

number of helpful: 2 of 31 people (6%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
												If you like the original, or think this one looks good, I'd recommend torrenting it. The main game was super fun, and then all of a sudden it went way downhill. The stealth parts sucked, but were fine and doable and everthing. But where the game utterly fails is the final chase sequence. In a game that rejoices in its own terrible controls, having a timed accuracy section was completely unreasonable. The final chase of this game is more inappropriate than the forced boss fights in Deus Ex: Human Revolution. The story was awesome though, and I definitely recommend trying it, but I don't recommend spending money on it. Let's just say I had less than thirty "deaths" before the final sequence, and I ended at an even 330 after it. And I've played the original all the way through, including the challenge stuff, so I don't think I'm that bad at these controls.
